questions.text:
5 year old child presented with jaundice, anemia and pigmented gall stones.
Peripheral smear shows following changes.
Pedigree analysis shows following inheritence pattern.
Which mutation is MOST commonly associated with this case
questions.solution: The child presents with jaundice, anemia, pigmented gallstones, and a peripheral smear showing spherocytes, all of which are classic features of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The pedigree suggests an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern. The SPTA1 gene encodes spectrin alpha chain, a key red cell membrane protein. Mutations in SPTA1 lead to membrane instability, resulting in spherocyte formation and hemolysis. While other genes like ANK1 and SPTB can also cause HS, SPTA1 is one of the most common mutations associated with this condition.

questions.text: An 8 year old girl with cola colored urine and mild facial puffiness. Creatinine was 2.2mg/dl. She has a history of impetigo. What is the associated electron microscopic finding?
questions.solution: This child presents with cola-colored urine, facial puffiness, elevated creatinine, and a recent history of impetigo, all suggestive of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN). On electron microscopy, the characteristic finding in PSGN is subepithelial immune complex deposits, also called "subepithelial humps". These humps are formed due to immune complex deposition following a streptococcal infection.

questions.text: 5 year old child with bleeding per rectum and rectal polyp showing colonic epithelium with mucin as shown in image below. This pathology is an example of:
questions.solution: This 5-year-old child presents with rectal bleeding and a polyp showing colonic epithelium with mucin, as seen in the image. The histology shows disorganized but mature colonic glands within the lamina propria, characteristic of a juvenile (retention) polyp, which is a type of hamartoma. Hamartomas are benign, non-neoplastic lesions made up of normal tissue elements in an abnormal configuration and are common in young children.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is associated with large segmental facial hemangiomas?
questions.solution:
PHACES syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder associated with large segmental facial hemangiomas, like the one seen in the image. The acronym PHACES stands for:

  • Posterior fossa brain malformations
  • Hemangiomas (large segmental facial)
  • Arterial anomalies
  • Cardiac defects (especially coarctation of the aorta)
  • Eye abnormalities
  • Sternal clefting or supraumbilical raphe
  • It primarily affects female infants and must be evaluated for associated anomalies when large facial hemangiomas are present.

questions.text: A child with recurrent otitis media, bloody diarrhea, and eczema is found to have thrombocytopenia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Recurrent infections (e.g., otitis media) due to combined B- and T-cell dysfunction
  • Eczema resembling atopic dermatitis
  • Thrombocytopenia with small platelets, often leading to bloody diarrhea
  • It is caused by mutations in the WAS gene, leading to defective cytoskeletal function in immune cells. Early diagnosis is critical for management and potential hematopoietic stem cell transplantation.

questions.text: Which disease will show the following mode of inheritance?
questions.solution:
The pedigree shows a pattern of X-linked recessive inheritance, where:

  • The condition predominantly affects males (black squares),
  • Carrier females (circles with a dot) pass the mutation to sons,
  • There is no male-to-male transmission, and affected males often have unaffected parents.
  • Wiskott-Aldrich Syndrome follows this inheritance pattern and is caused by mutations in the WAS gene on the X chromosome. This explains why only males are affected and carrier females can transmit the disease to their sons.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents with hemoptysis, dyspnea, and fatigue. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral alveolar infiltrates. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) confirms alveolar hemorrhage. A biopsy shows involvement of medium and small-sized blood vessels, but no granulomas are seen. Renal involvement is also suspected.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Microscopic polyangiitis is a small to medium vessel vasculitis that typically presents with pulmonary-renal syndrome, including alveolar hemorrhage (causing hemoptysis and dyspnea) and glomerulonephritis. Histologically, it shows necrotizing vasculitis without granuloma formation, which distinguishes it from Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Wegener’s). The absence of granulomas and the presence of renal and pulmonary involvement support the diagnosis of MPA. It is commonly associated with p-ANCA (MPO-ANCA).

1. TTN -D (AD DCM): Titin (TTN) mutations are a common cause of autosomal dominant dilated cardiomyopathy (DCM).
  2. Tafazzin-E (Left ventricular non-compaction): Tafazzin gene mutations are linked to Barth syndrome, which includes LV non-compaction.
  3. Dystrophin-C (X-linked DCM): Dystrophin mutations, seen in Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies, cause X-linked DCM.
  4. Myosin binding protein C- B (HOCM): Mutations in this sarcomeric protein are a frequent cause of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HOCM).
  5. ATTR-A (Restrictive cardiomyopathy): Transthyretin amyloidosis (ATTR) leads to amyloid infiltration of the myocardium, causing restrictive cardiomyopathy.

choices.text: Uremia due to chronic renal failure

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of progressively worsening abdominal distension over the past 6 months. He reports chronic diarrhea with bulky, foul-smelling stools and noticeable weight loss despite a normal appetite. He also describes episodes of blurred vision and difficulty seeing at night for the last several months. Additionally, he has experienced numbness and tingling in his hands and feet, as well as occasional muscle weakness.On examination, the patient has a protuberant abdomen with mild hepatomegaly. Neurological examination reveals decreased proprioception and vibration sense in the lower limbs and areflexia. Fundoscopic examination shows signs of retinal degeneration.Routine blood work is performed, and a peripheral blood smear reveals the presence of abnormally shaped red blood cells.Based on the clinical history and peripheral smear findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Abetalipoproteinemia is the correct diagnosis. It is a rare inherited disorder caused by a defect in the microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene, leading to an inability to form apolipoprotein B-containing lipoproteins. This results in fat malabsorption, leading to steatorrhea, failure to thrive, and fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies (notably vitamin E). The neurological symptoms (ataxia, neuropathy), retinal degeneration, and acanthocytosis (spiky RBCs seen on smear) are classic findings. The patient's GI symptoms, neuro signs, and smear confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of several months of worsening fatigue, night sweats, and unintentional weight loss. He also mentions a feeling of fullness in his left upper abdomen. On physical examination, there is noticeable splenomegaly extending 5 cm below the costal margin. There is no significant lymphadenopathy.A complete blood count (CBC) reveals a markedly elevated white blood cell count. A peripheral blood smear shows a predominance of mature granulocytes at various stages of maturation, along with marked basophilia. Platelet count is 5.5 lakh/cu-mm and hemoglobin of 10g/dl.Given the clinical picture and smear findings, a chromosomal analysis is performed.Which chromosomal abnormality is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution: The correct answer is A. t(9;22), which is the Philadelphia chromosome associated with Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML). CML typically presents with fatigue, weight loss, night sweats, splenomegaly, and marked leukocytosis with mature and immature granulocytes (e.g., myelocytes, metamyelocytes) on peripheral smear. Basophilia is a key diagnostic clue. The t(9;22) translocation results in the BCR-ABL fusion gene, leading to uncontrolled tyrosine kinase activity and myeloproliferation.

questions.text: Which kinase is essential for the initiation of necroptosis downstream of TNFR1?
questions.solution: RIPK1 plays a central role in necroptosis, a form of programmed necrosis triggered when apoptosis is inhibited. Upon activation of TNFR1 (Tumor Necrosis Factor Receptor 1), RIPK1 interacts with RIPK3, leading to the formation of the necrosome complex. This ultimately activates MLKL (mixed lineage kinase domain-like protein), which disrupts the plasma membrane, causing cell death. Unlike PI3K, JAK2, or MAPK, RIPK1 is specifically essential for initiating necroptosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with newly diagnosed Burkitt lymphoma develops nausea, vomiting, and seizures 2 days after starting chemotherapy. Labs show elevated uric acid, potassium, and phosphate with low calcium. Which of the following is not a component of Cairo-Bishop laboratory criteria
questions.solution:
The Cairo-Bishop laboratory criteria are used to diagnose tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) and include:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hypokalemia is not part of the criteria; in fact, hyperkalemia is typical due to massive tumor cell lysis releasing intracellular potassium.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male with aplastic anemia underwent transfusion 2 weeks ago. He now presents with fever, rash, diarrhea, and pancytopenia. Bone marrow biopsy reveals aplasia.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: TA-GVHD is a rare but often fatal complication of blood transfusion, especially in immunocompromised patients such as those with aplastic anemia. It occurs when viable donor T lymphocytes in the transfused blood engraft and attack the recipient's tissues. Symptoms typically develop within 1-2 weeks post-transfusion and include fever, rash, diarrhea, liver dysfunction, and pancytopenia due to bone marrow aplasia. Prevention involves irradiating blood products to inactivate donor lymphocytes.

questions.text:
A newborn fails to pass meconium within the first 48 hours of life. Hirschsprung disease is suspected. In this condition, the absence of ganglion cells affects specific layers of the intestinal wall.
Which of the following layers are affected by the absence of ganglion cells in this condition?
A. Epithelial layer
B. Muscular layer
C. Serosa
D. Submucosa
Select the correct combination:
questions.solution: In Hirschsprung disease, there is a congenital absence of ganglion cells in both the myenteric (Auerbach) plexus located in the muscular layer, and the submucosal (Meissner) plexus located in the submucosa. This absence leads to a lack of coordinated peristalsis and causes functional intestinal obstruction. The affected segment becomes spastic and contracted, leading to failure to pass meconium in newborns.

questions.text: 45 year male presents with increased mast cells . which of the following is not used to stain mast cells
questions.solution: Mast cells are typically stained using Giemsa, Toluidine blue, and Chloroacetate esterase, which highlight their granules due to high histamine and heparin content. Non-specific esterase stains are primarily used for monocytes and monocytic leukemias, not mast cells, making it unsuitable for identifying mast cell populations.

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for PCR testing
questions.solution: EDTA (ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid) is the anticoagulant of choice for PCR (polymerase chain reaction) testing because it chelates divalent cations like magnesium and calcium, preventing coagulation without interfering with DNA integrity. Unlike heparin, which can inhibit DNA polymerase, EDTA preserves nucleic acids and allows for accurate amplification. Sodium fluoride is used primarily in glucose testing, and trisodium citrate is typically used for coagulation studies

choices.text: Mature single-stranded miRNAs has size of 21 to 30 nucleotides
The human genome encodes almost 6000 miRNA genes

questions.text: Which is the not true about image shown below on mi RNA?
questions.solution: Synthetic siRNAs are used for gene knockdown, not knock-out. Knockdown reduces gene expression temporarily, whereas gene knock-out involves permanent removal or inactivation of a gene (often done via CRISPR or homologous recombination). The image correctly illustrates the miRNA pathway, where miRNAs cause post-transcriptional gene silencing by binding to target mRNAs and either degrading them or inhibiting translation. The rest of the statements are accurate.

choices.text: Loss or reduced expression of MHC molecules.
Tumor cells induce expression of the inhibitory receptor CTLA-4 on tumor-specific T cells.

questions.text: Immune responses often fail to check tumor growth because cancers evade immune recognition or resist immune effector mechanisms. Which of the following is not a tumor evasion mechanism
questions.solution:
• T regulatory (Treg) cells normally suppress immune responses to maintain self-tolerance and prevent autoimmunity. Tumors often recruit or enhance Treg cells to suppress anti-tumor immune responses, thereby promoting immune evasion. Therefore, inhibiting Tregs would actually enhance immune response against tumors-not help the tumor evade it.
  • The other options describe true mechanisms of tumor immune evasion, such as loss of MHC, antigen variation, and expression of inhibitory receptors like CTLA-4.

questions.text: Match the Genetic Technique with Its Description:

A 60-year-old postmenopausal woman presents with abdominal bloating and weight loss. CT shows a bilateral ovarian mass with solid and cystic components. Histology reveals psammoma bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Serous cystadenocarcinoma is the most common malignant ovarian tumor, especially in postmenopausal women. It often presents bilaterally with solid and cystic components. A key histological feature is the presence of psammoma bodies-concentrically laminated calcifications-which are characteristic of serous tumors. Symptoms like abdominal bloating and weight loss are common due to peritoneal spread. This distinguishes it from mucinous tumors, which are typically unilateral and larger.
